article.headline: Trump raised 5 times as much money from Americaâs top CEOs as Biden
article.body: As the Nov. 3 election sparks record campaign contributions, the CEOs of S&P 500 companies are helping to fund the war chests of President Donald Trump and challenger Joe Biden, while also contributing to other Republican and Democratic politicians. In their political giving as individuals, these chief executives have combined to give more to Trump than Biden. Some 15 CEOs whose companies are components of the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% have donated a total of $2.489 million to Trumpâs principal campaign committee, its joint fundraising groups with the Republican National Committee or pro-Trump super PACs. Meanwhile, 30 chief execs have contributed $536,100 to Bidenâs main campaign committee, its joint groups with the Democratic National Committee or pro-Biden super PACs. These figures come from a MarketWatch analysis of processed Federal Election Commission data on individual contributions made between January 2019 and August 2020. Anyone who held the CEO job in 2019 or 2020 at a company that was part of the S&P 500 is included. As shown in the table below, the S&P CEOs giving the most to Trump were Intercontinental Exchangeâs ICE, -0.04% Â Jeffrey Sprecher, whose wife, Republican Sen. Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, faces a tough Senate race, and Las Vegas Sandsâs LVS, -0.84% Â Sheldon Adelson, a longtime major GOP donor. Also ranking high in dollar amounts donated were Vornado Realty Trustâs VNO, -3.13% Â Steven Roth and Oracleâs ORCL, +0.42% Â Safra Catz.S&P 500 CEOs giving their own money to Trumpâs campaign CEO Company Amount Recipient Sector 1. Trump for President Energy Total $2,489,491.34 * Former CEO who held the position during the FECâs 2020 election cycle that started Jan. 1, 2019 Source: MarketWatch analysis of processed Federal Election Commission data on individual contributions made between January 2019 and August 2020 The S&P 500 bosses donating the most to Biden were Disneyâs DIS, +1.53% Â Bob Iger, who is currently the entertainment companyâs executive chairman after leaving the CEO post in February, as well as Amphenolâs APH, -0.00% Richard Norwitt, DuPontâs DD, +0.06% Edward Breen, Merckâs MRK, -0.14% Â Kenneth Frazier and Vertex Pharmaceuticalsâs VRTX, +0.52% Â Jeffrey Leiden. Overall spending in this yearâs election will approach $11 billion, easily topping the $7 billion spent (in todayâs dollars) in the 2016 election, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit group that tracks money in politics. One CEO, MGM Resorts Internationalâs MGM, -2.59% Â Bill Hornbuckle, gave to both Trump and Biden, according to MarketWatchâs analysis of disclosures. He contributed $17,501 to the Trump Victory Fund, a joint fundraising committee with the RNC, plus the maximum amount of $5,600 to Trumpâs primary campaign committee. He donated $2,800 to Bidenâs main campaign committee. Related:These are the basics of campaign finance in 2020 â in two handy charts And see:Politicians keep coordinating with super PACs and other supposedly independent groups, study findsS&P 500 CEOs giving their own money to Bidenâs campaign Company Amount Recipient Sector 1. Devin Stockfish Weyerhaeuser $1,500.00 Biden for President Real Estate Total $536,100.00 * Former CEO who held the position during the FECâs 2020 election cycle that started Jan. 1, 2019 ** Former S&P 500 company that was a component of the index during the FECâs 2020 election cycle that started Jan. 1, 2019 Source: MarketWatch analysis of processed Federal Election Commission data on individual contributions made between January 2019 and August 2020 CEOs who have donated to Trumpâs campaign may be showing that theyâre pleased with his policies, such as the 2017 tax cuts, said Michael Beckel, research director at Issue One, a nonpartisan watchdog group that aims to reduce the influence of big money in politics. âSome corporate executives may see their political contributions as good investments in policies that will benefit them,â Beckel told MarketWatch in an email. Many of them âsee themselves as having a fiduciary responsibility to be active in politics.â Execs also may donate âbased on their own political preferences and ideological leanings,â even as their political contributions could âcarry some risks for companies,â Beckel said. âAn executiveâs giving could turn off a segment of customers from their brand, and even lead to protests or boycotts.â Bruce Freed, president of the Center for Political Accountability, a nonprofit that pushes for better disclosure of corporate political activity, also noted the potential challenges for CEOs as they vote with their wallets. âCompanies today face very serious risks â both reputational risks and bottom-line risks â for contributions that companies are making,â Freed said in an interview. The donations can âconflict with their core values and positionsâ on issues such as racial justice or climate change, he said, adding that his organization has explored the situation in its âConflicted Consequencesâ and âCollision Courseâ reports. âAll of these things have made political spending much more controversial for companies and executives â and much riskier,â he said. Related:Watchdog says Washingtonâs growing swampier, even as coronavirus lockdowns let Congress climb off âhamster wheel of fundraisingâ And see:S&P 500 companies are protecting themselves from todayâs inflamed politics, study findsCompaniesâ responses Intercontinental Exchange, Las Vegas Sands, Vornado Realty, Oracle, Disney, DuPont, Merck, Amphenol and Vertex didnât respond to requests for comment. Oracleâs Catz worked in 2016 on Trumpâs transition team, while Disneyâs Iger and Merckâs Frazier are among the executives who have shown their opposition to the presidentâs actions by resigning from his White House councils. Iger cited Trumpâs withdrawal from the Paris climate agreement, and Frazier was responding to the presidentâs initial reaction to racial violence in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017. A spokeswoman for Wells Fargo WFC, , whose former chief executive, Tim Sloan, gave to Trumpâs campaign, said his donation âwas a personal contribution and was in no way related to his time as CEO of Wells Fargo, which ended a year and a half ago.â A Waste Management spokesman said the company doesnât comment on the âpersonal political contributions of our employees.â Among the Biden donors, a Boston Properties BXP, -1.65% Â spokeswoman said âpersonal political contributionsâ made by the companyâs CEO or other employees are âpersonal decisions.â A Marriott International MAR, -0.96% spokeswoman said the hotel company âwill not be commenting on any personal contributions made by our CEO or any other executive,â and a Tripadvisor TRIP, +0.74% Â spokesman said the travel company does ânot comment on the personal contributions made by employees or executives within this company.â A Henry Schein HSIC, -1.03% Â spokeswoman said the health-care products company âmakes no national political campaign contributions, per its Worldwide Business Standards,â and âindividual contributions are just that â individual donations that have nothing to do with the company.â Netflix NFLX, +1.43%, Nielsen NLSN, -4.77% and Broadridge Financial Solutions BR, +1.28% Â declined to comment. The other companies listed in the tables above didnât respond to requests for comment.S&P 500 CEOs give much more to Republicans The higher dollar total for Trumpâs campaign aligns with how Republican groups overall have attracted more money from S&P 500 CEOs than Democratic groups. Some 179 of these CEOs donated a total of $35.61 million of their own money to Republican candidates and organizations, while 148 bosses combined to contribute $3.172 million to Democratic efforts, according to MarketWatchâs analysis of outlays between January 2019 and August 2020. Most of the GOPâs big advantage comes from Las Vegas Sandsâs Adelson, who has given $26.38 million to Republicans, including $25 million to the Senate Leadership Fund, a super PAC aiming to protect and expand on the GOP majority in the U.S. Senate. But even with Adelson excluded, Republicans come out ahead in drawing donations from the S&P CEOs, with $9.233 million in 2019 and 2020, tripling the Democratic haul. Related: Democratsâ chances of Senate takeover rise, and that could affect health care, energy and financial services And see:If the Democrats win the Senate, Big Tech better be ready for a bigger fight Many of the S&P CEOs â 81 of them, to be exact â contributed to both Republican and Democratic groups. In other words, only 98 of the 179 GOP donors gave just to the GOP, and only 67 of the Democratic donors gave just to that partyâs groups. The greater giving to Republicans by the S&P CEOs in the current election cycle fits with their past behavior. Ahead of the 2018 midterm elections, a MarketWatch analysis found 200 S&P chief execs had given a total of $7.4 million to the GOP, while 149 donated a total of $2.6 million to Democrats. MarketWatchâs analysis here doesnât cover political contributions by current or former executives of privately held companies, such as billionaire Michael Bloomberg, as it focuses instead on chief executives of the S&P 500âs large, publicly traded companies. Now read:Biden topped Trump in cash on hand as September began And see:Trump says he might spend his own money on his re-election campaign This report was first published on Oct. 8, 2020.
